div.head: Extra word on top block, Southern Face B

app.note: One could also read cāṅ.However, other occurrences in the inscription, e.g. l. A26, present a clearer case of vāṅ. Moreover, we note several occurences of dalaṁ vāṅ in C. 252.
On some estampages, a faint subscript character seems to be engraved underneath the -tā (or above l. A25), but in reality, it is more likely a damage on the stone.
See C. 149 for an occurence of the toponym Ajaun Curaiḥ.
The -pa seems to have been engraved under the -la, probably an initial oversight by the scribe.

This reading is purely conjectural, because the other occurrences of mvaun are all followed by the term paliy and because the second syllable of the word seems to bear a vowel -i. However, it seems possible to decipher a subscrit -va under the first akṣara.
See l. B2 for a clearer occurence of this toponym.
Correction from Eade, who suggests astronomical factors favor reading jhaṣabhṛguje. The meter does so too.

div.head: Main text
div.p: Rizière Vr̥nac ; rizière Talavār : depuis la confluence vavaḥ du ruisseau Cyās jusqu'à la pierre de bornage des quatre tertres Cagur, jusqu'au ruisseau Cyās Lagaih ; continuer suivant la pierre de bornage jusqu'à la pierre de bornage du jardin Tranāṅ ; continuer suivant la pierre de bornage jusqu'à la pierre de bornage en tête de la rizière Talavār ; continuer suivant la pierre de bornage jusqu'à la pierre de bornage auprès de la rivière Tamukūr et du ruisseau Talavār Lagaih Ur ; continuer suivant cette rivière jusqu'à retourner à l'embouchure du ruisseau Cyās.

Les rizières repiquées à cette période : deux-cents cinquante-cinq parcelles galauk, quatre-vingt-cinq jāk de contenu. Les pépinière : soixante-cinq parcelles, quarante-cinq jāk de contenu. Tous les cakir Alaḥ lagaiḥ.

La rizière La : depuis l'embouchure du ruisseau Satāṅ, aller au nord suivant la rivière jusqu'à l'embouchure de la rivière Valāṅ, aller à l'ouest suivant la rivière jusqu'à la pierre de bornage Valāṅ, allez au sud en suivant la pierre de bornage jusqu'à la pierre de bornage Candrā du ruisseau , jusqu'à la pierre de bornage de la digue à eau Ajvañ Curaih .
Les champs repiqués à cette époque : cinq cent trente parcelles, deux cent vingt jāk de contenu.. cakir lagaih. Tous ces chers champs salés du ruisseau Satāṅ Lac.

At the bottom of the Northern face C, a symbol marks the end of the last line, and is reproduced identically at the beggining of the Western face D, indicating the progression of the text. Simultaneously, the word written at the end of face C is interrupted after one syllable, and continues at the beginning of face D : ka- (l. C29) -rov (l. D1), karov. This method of indicating where the text continues through symbols is unique in the Indrapura's corpus. At the end of face D, a different symbol, in the shape of a cross, is written and the last word galauk is also interrupted after two syllables: galau-. However, none of the cam parts of the pillar's three other faces bears this same symbol, and no trace of the missing -k can be found. Was the text continuing on another artefact, yet to be discovered?

Unpublished inscription. First edition of cam parts by Salomé Pichon based on the BNF estampages, on the EFEO estampages made by Nguyen Van Quang, on photos and photogrammetry models made by Adeline Leviver, and on a direct reading on stone led in July 2022.
